<IntroSection>

## What is this?

Tags represent a status, or a common denominator. They make sections and entities quickly identifiable and searchable.

</IntroSection>

<PageSection
  id={tabToc.overview[1].id}
  title={tabToc.overview[1].value}
>

<PageSection
  id={tabToc.overview[2].id}
  title={tabToc.overview[2].value}
  explanation="By default, the variant property has the 'lightBlue' value, but you can also set it to the following values: 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'cyan', 'teal', 'gray', 'purple' and 'pink'."
>

```jsx live
<Inline>
  <Tag label="Short text" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="red" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="orange" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="green" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="cyan" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="teal" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="gray" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="purple" />
  <Tag label="Short text" variant="pink" />
</Inline>
```

</PageSection >

<PageSection
  id={tabToc.overview[3].id}
  title={tabToc.overview[3].value}
  explanation="By default, the size property has a 'normal' value, but you can also set it to 'large'."
>

```jsx live
<Inline>
  <Tag label="Short text" size="normal" />
  <Tag label="Short text" size="large" />
</Inline>
```

</PageSection>
</PageSection>
</Panel>

```jsx isStatic
import { Tag } from '@vtex/admin-ui'

function Example() {
  return <Tag label="Short text" />
}
```

1. Use semantic colors that have a clear and contextualized meaning in your application, such as green for success and red for errors. However, if your application employs a richer palette with unambiguous usage of colors don't hesitate to use your Tags with them.
2. They should always be read-only.
